Y Dirprwy Lywydd / The Deputy Presiding Officer:
Trefn, trefn. The National Assembly is now in session.

11.text: Mike Hedges: 1. What recent discussions has

14.text:
the First Minister had in relation to policing
in Wales? OAQ(4)1374(FM)

16.text:
Carwyn Jones: I have not had any recent discussions
personally, but my colleague Lesley Griffiths,

22.text:
the Minister for Local Government and Government
Business, holds regular meetings with the

25.text:
chief constables and police and crime commissioners.
Mike Hedges: With policing devolved to Scotland

32.text:
and Northern Ireland, as well as to the Länder
in Germany and to the Spanish regions—excluding

36.text:
items such as border control and terrorism—do
you agree that policing should be devolved

41.text:
to Wales now?
Carwyn Jones: Yes, I think that there is a

44.text:
very strong case for devolving policing to
Wales. It is the only emergency service—on

49.text:
land, at least—that has not been devolved.
It makes sense, as the fire service and, of

54.text:
course, the ambulance service have been devolved,
for policing to follow suit. That is the evidence

58.text:
that the Welsh Government has given to the
Silk commission.

61.text:
Byron Davies: First Minister, could you confirm
to the Chamber whether you participated, in

67.text:
any form, in Lord Stevens's commission for
the Labour Party into the future of policing,

72.text:
and, specifically, whether you agree with
the Labour Party recommendation of having

75.text:
only one police force in Wales?
Carwyn Jones: There are three recommendations.

79.text:
One recommendation is that there should be
one police force for Wales; I do not think

82.text:
that we can go that far. What is required
first is the devolution of policing, and it

86.text:
will then be a matter for the Assembly to
decide what the shape of the constabularies

89.text:
in Wales would be in the future.
Rhun ap Iorwerth: Roeddwn yn falch o glywed

95.text:
eich ateb funud yn ôl, Brif Weinidog. Roeddwn
yn cael trafodaeth gydag un o uwch-swyddogion

99.text:
Heddlu Gogledd Cymru rai dyddiau yn ôl a
oedd yn dweud eu bod yn awyddus i gydweithio

104.text:
llawer mwy â'r gwasanaeth tân, ond bod
teimlad nad oedd Llywodraeth Cymru am weld

107.text:
hynny'n digwydd oherwydd mai dim ond un
ohonynt, sef y gwasanaeth tân, a oedd wedi

113.text:
cael ei ddatganoli. O ystyried eich cefnogaeth
i ddatganoli'r heddlu, onid yw'n gwneud

117.text:
synnwyr, felly, y byddai datganoli'r heddlu,
ynghyd â'r system gyfiawnder troseddol,

120.text:
yn helpu'r math hwnnw o gydweithredu ar
bob lefel?

122.text:
Carwyn Jones: Mae cydweithio'n digwydd yn
awr, wrth gwrs. Maent yn siarad â'i gilydd,

127.text:
ac mae'r gwasanaethau argyfwng yn rhan o'r
'resilience forum' hefyd—mae'n bwysig

130.text:
pwysleisio hynny. Yn ogystal â hyn, mae'r
heddlu'n gweithio'n agos gyda ni, fel

133.text:
Llywodraeth. Dyna pam, yn ein barn ni, ei
bod yn beth call i symud i sefyllfa lle bo'r

139.text:
hyn sy'n digwydd yn awr yn cael ei wneud
yn ffurfiol yn y dyfodol.

145.text:
Lynne Neagle: 2. A wnaiff y Prif Weinidog
ddatganiad am flaenoriaethau Llywodraeth Cymru

151.text:
yng nghyswllt yr amgylchedd yn Nhorfaen? OAQ(4)1385(FM)
Carwyn Jones: The programme for government

156.text:
and the Minister for Natural Resources and
Food's autumn statement set out our priorities

164.text:
for the environment across Wales.
Lynne Neagle: First Minister, will you join

167.text:
me in commending the Minister for Housing
and Regeneration for doing the right thing

171.text:
by the people of Varteg, and rejecting plans
to opencast that would have threatened the

177.text:
viability of a school, jeopardised the UNESCO
world heritage site, and blighted an entire

183.text:
community? However, as we look to the future,
will you now work with the Minister to draw

187.text:
upon the very important lessons from this
case, ensuring that communities such as Varteg

192.text:
never again have to endure years of crippling
uncertainty, particularly when we have a minerals

196.text:
technical advice note in place that is meant
to protect them?

199.text:
Carwyn Jones: I am very much aware of the
number of occasions on which the Member has

205.text:
raised the issue of Varteg in the Chamber.
She has made the views of her constituents

209.text:
very clearly known. She will appreciate, of
course, that, given that we are within the

215.text:
six-week period for a legal challenge of the
Minister's decision, I cannot comment on

219.text:
the application itself. However, nevertheless,
with regard to the planning system generally,

224.text:
we have the planning reform Bill that is being
taken forward now, and further consideration

229.text:
will be given to a planning Bill in the future,
during the course of this Assembly as well.

237.text:
William Graham: First Minister, Torfaen County
Borough Council is today quite likely to agree

242.text:
its local development plan, which provides
for a large number of housing. It is difficult

245.text:
to quite see why it needs so many within the
plan, although it does extend for many years.

249.text:
Much of that housing is on greenfield sites.
How does that conflict with your environmental

253.text:
policies?
Carwyn Jones: We, of course, have to examine

256.text:
any potential LDP, and it is for the Minister
to decide what action he may or may not wish

261.text:
to take with regard to any LDP during the
adoption process.

268.text:
Lindsay Whittle: First Minister, I have a
similar question to that of my colleague William

271.text:
Graham. So far, Torfaen has a good rating
for air quality. However, with the prospect

277.text:
of a further almost 5,000 homes to be built
in Torfaen, what safeguards can be put in

283.text:
place to ensure that the degree of air pollution
in Torfaen will not seriously deteriorate?

287.text:
Carwyn Jones: I do not see how there is necessarily
a correlation between housing and air pollution.

292.text:
If people are able to live closer to where
they work, that will reduce air pollution.

297.text:
We would, of course, expect any local authority
when developing its LDP to assess the need

303.text:
for housing in any particular area and, of
course, to produce an LDP that takes into

309.text:
account all of the planning guidance that
the Welsh Government has issued.

312.text:
Y Dirprwy Lywydd / The Deputy Presiding Officer:
I now call the party leaders to question the

315.text:
First Minister. The leader of the opposition,
Andrew R.T. Davies.

319.text:
Andrew R.T. Davies: First Minister, today
we had the very disappointing news that the

324.text:
Programme for International Student Assessment
results have been depressingly bad again.

328.text:
The Organisation for Economic Co-operation
and Development says that today's education

331.text:
is tomorrow's economy. With the figures
that we have seen today and the successive

335.text:
falls in our performance, does it not make
for bleak reading and, in particular, a bleak

339.text:
future for our economy?
Carwyn Jones: First of all, I have to say

343.text:
that even though we have seen some improvement,
particularly in reading, the figures are disappointing

348.text:
overall. That cannot be got away from. Nevertheless,
we should remember that the PISA results are

356.text:
with regard to a particular set of tests and
not a reflection of the education system as

360.text:
a whole. What I can do is to remind Members
of what has been put in place since the last

367.text:
set of PISA results in 2009. This includes
the national literacy and numeracy programme;

372.text:
the national support programme and the fact
that every school in Wales now has an NSP

375.text:
partner who acts as a mentor; the changes
that have been made to supporting professional

380.text:
development, particularly performance management
of teachers from January 2012; the development

385.text:
of the induction process for newly qualified
teachers; and, of course, Teach First Wales,

390.text:
which has been contracted to deliver a school
improvement employment-based teacher training

394.text:
system across Wales. In addition, 150 trainees
have been placed into secondary schools that

399.text:
have been targeted as having a high percentage
of pupils living in deprived communities.

403.text:
We have focused on leadership development,
particularly the revision of the national

407.text:
professional qualification for headship, and
we have published new leadership standards

412.text:
and developed leadership capacity. We have
strengthened school accountability through

416.text:
school banding and the termly stocktakes.
We have Learning Wales, launched in September

421.text:
2012, the national model for regional working
and, of course, the—[Interruption.]—well,

427.text:
the Plaid Cymru benches complain that I do
not give answers. This, I suspect, is an answer

431.text:
that they want, so I would suggest that there
is no point in complaining about it. So, we

436.text:
have, of course, the improvements that have
been made in terms of attendance and behaviour.

439.text:
Carwyn Jones: Now, it will take some time
for these measures to bear full fruit. The

445.text:
previous Minister for education and the present
one have both said that we wish to be in the

448.text:
top 20 by 2015. Michael Gove, of course, has
said that it will take 10 years to improve

453.text:
the situation in England. We think that that
is an overestimation.

455.text:
Andrew R.T. Davies: I think that that is the
longest answer that I have ever had in First

461.text:
Minister's questions. Even though you started
by saying that there has been some improvement,

466.text:
whichever way you cut it, First Minister,
these figures today are depressingly bad,

471.text:
but, unfortunately, depressingly familiar
to a Labour First Minister, whose party has

476.text:
been running education in Wales for 14 years.
The previous Minister for education, in a

482.text:
letter that he put out in 2010, clearly thought
the same when he said,

487.text:
Andrew R.T. Davies: 'These results cannot
be argued away or excused.'

491.text:
Andrew R.T. Davies: He went on to say that
the results could not be excused on the basis

495.text:
of low socioeconomic status or the bilingual
nature of our nation or education system.

502.text:
The list that you just gave us could, no doubt,
have been read at any juncture when previous

507.text:
PISA results have been reported. The problem
is, First Minister, that educationalists,

516.text:
students and parents are fed up of listening
to Labour's excuses. How can we genuinely

523.text:
have confidence that what you outlined in
your answer to me will make a difference this

529.text:
time around?
Carwyn Jones: You clearly did not listen to

531.text:
the answer that I gave. I said that this is
what has been put in place since 2009. The

536.text:
second point that I would make to him is that
we have constantly said that it will take

540.text:
time for these measures to have an effect.
What some people in Wales would like to know,

544.text:
perhaps, is what exactly he quibbles with
in terms of what I have just read out as an

548.text:
answer to him. What would he have done differently?
How does he explain to the people of Wales

552.text:
that his party wants to cut education spending
by between 12% and 20%? How would that help

557.text:
to improve PISA results in the future? Maybe
if he had some credibility on this point in

563.text:
terms of a developed alternative, if he had
some credibility in terms of wanting to increase

569.text:
school spending—as we are doing, of course,
through our manifesto commitment to protecting

573.text:
school spending in Wales—then he might have
some credibility. It would be interesting

578.text:
for the Chamber to understand what he disagrees
with in terms of what the Government is doing

583.text:
and why he thinks that education spending
should be cut.

586.text:
Andrew R.T. Davies: I think that it is quite
shameful that, on a day when we have had more

591.text:
damning evidence of educational failure under
Labour, you cannot show any humility to the

598.text:
people of Wales who have depended on education
as a route out of poverty, a route to good

605.text:
jobs, and, above all, a route to develop an
economy fit for the twenty-first century.

610.text:
Are you seriously telling me, First Minister,
that the previous Ministers for education

614.text:
before 2009 got it wholly wrong? If you are,
will you apologise on their behalf as the

621.text:
leader of Welsh Labour? What can we expect
when the new results come out in 2015? Will

628.text:
you now take control and ultimately put your
reputation on the line by saying that we will

633.text:
see the improvement that we require in 2015
to make the economic prospects of this country

638.text:
far better? If you will not, you really should
reflect on your position, First Minister.

644.text:
Carwyn Jones: In response to the leader of
the opposition, I would like to say that I

649.text:
went to a comprehensive school. I have a stake
in the state system, and that is what I am

656.text:
proud of. It is a shameful reflection of the
UK that of all the Prime Ministers and First

662.text:
Ministers there have ever been, only one has
come from a comprehensive school and that

664.text:
is me. That is a shameful reflection, and
his party has made it worse. He sits with

671.text:
his old Etonian Prime Minister and the private
school boys who sit on those benches, and

676.text:
he lectures us about state education. [Interruption.]
He did not listen to what I said. There is

681.text:
no point in whining about it at the top of
his voice.

685.text:
Carwyn Jones: These results are not good enough.
These results have to be improved on. Yes,

695.text:
reading has improved, but we still have to
make sure that there is improvement in the

699.text:
future. I offered him the opportunity to comment
on what we as a Government are doing, but

705.text:
he could give no view. I offered him the opportunity
to justify the appalling cuts that he wants

712.text:
to impose on schools in Wales, but he failed
to justify those cuts. He makes a lot of noise,

722.text:
but he has no substance and no policies.
Carwyn Jones: We accept our responsibilities.

728.text:
We accept that we must work with teachers
and parents to continue to improve the education

734.text:
system in Wales, and we have seen an improvement
in GCSE results this year, and that is why

741.text:
we will continue to deliver for the people
of Wales, even as the party opposite shouts

747.text:
and does not want to do anything more than
cut education spending. It suggests the phrase

752.text:
'class war' and what it wants to do is
to cut spending for the poorest in society

757.text:
and on state schools, and that is exactly
what the Tories stand for. We will stand up

764.text:
for our responsibilities; we accept responsibilities
for these results and we have put in place

768.text:
a system that will help to improve education
in Wales, whereas what we get from the Conservative

772.text:
benches is empty rhetoric.
Y Dirprwy Lywydd / The Deputy Presiding Officer:

776.text:
Order. I have said before that this is not
a library and far less a monastery, but there

781.text:
is far too much shouting going on and not
enough listening, and that is not good scrutiny.

786.text:
I now call the leader of Plaid Cymru, Leanne
Wood.

789.text:
Leanne Wood: First Minister, you are the leader
of this country, and you are failing to show

795.text:
leadership on this. You said that your term
of office would be all about delivery, and

801.text:
you told us that you expected to see improvement
in our PISA results in December. It is now

808.text:
December. Today, you have delivered the worst
set of PISA results in western Europe. Are

815.text:
you now going to take full responsibility
for those results?

819.text:
Carwyn Jones: As I said to the leader of the
opposition, we accept as a Government that

824.text:
there needs to be improvement with regard
to PISA, as, indeed, your party did when you

828.text:
were in Government between 2007 and 2011.
There has been some improvement; it is far

835.text:
from enough. There needs to be more improvement
in terms of reading and maths—we know that

840.text:
that is true of the whole of the UK, incidentally.
Things have not been particularly good in

843.text:
England, Scotland or Northern Ireland either.
I do not use that as excuse, because I see

848.text:
the figures in front of me, as far as Wales
is concerned. However, I have already outlined

852.text:
in some detail what we as a Government have
put forward in order to deal with the situation

856.text:
and to improve the PISA results in 2015. Unless
there is something in the Government's programme

862.text:
that you disagree with or that you think should
be improved, which I am all ears about, this

867.text:
is what we plan to do as a Government to improve
things.

869.text:
Leanne Wood: First Minister, Wales is number
43 on the list in terms of maths, number 41

875.text:
in terms of reading and number 36 in terms
of science. As a parent, I do not accept that

881.text:
any of our children are any less capable than
the children in Scotland, Ireland or England.

889.text:
Scotland also has large pockets of deprivation,
but it substantially outperforms Wales, even

896.text:
though it has the same set of tools for delivering
those results. If the Scottish Government

903.text:
can deliver good results, why cannot you?
Carwyn Jones: That is the challenge for us,

908.text:
and we have to ensure that, by 2015, we deliver
those results. In fairness, the two Ministers

913.text:
for education have said that what we have
put in place will take some time to work its

917.text:
way through. Michael Gove was talking about
10 years. I think that that is an overestimate

922.text:
of what it will take, although who knows what
they need to do in England? As far as Wales

926.text:
is concerned, we have consistently said that
what was put in place after PISA 2009 would

931.text:
take some time to have its fullest effect.
We have seen an improvement in reading, but,

935.text:
let us face it, overall it is not good. We
need to make sure that things improve in 2015.

939.text:
Leanne Wood: Let us look at the question of
implementation, then, shall we? There have

943.text:
been delays in the implementation of your
policies, such as regional consortia and the

948.text:
recently introduced national literacy and
numeracy framework. These delays mean that

955.text:
we will miss your Government's 2015 improvement
targets. Is it not the case, First Minister,

962.text:
that if your Government was a local authority
it would now be in special measures? Can you

968.text:
tell us why parents should continue to trust
your Government with their children's education?

975.text:
Carwyn Jones: It is because we have delivered
the foundation phase; because we have delivered

978.text:
the Welsh baccalaureate; because we have protected
school spending in a way that is not there

982.text:
in the rest of the UK; because we have seen
the improvement in GCSE results in Wales and

987.text:
the gap with England being closed; because
we have seen the education maintenance allowance

991.text:
being kept in Wales, when it disappeared in
England; and because we have ensured that

995.text:
students in Wales are able to go to university
without an enormous debt hanging around their

999.text:
heads when they leave university. So, we have
to remember that the PISA results are a reflection

1005.text:
of part of the system in Wales, namely children's
ability to take tests, and we have to rectify

1010.text:
that, but it would not be right to say that
education in Wales is in some kind of crisis.

1014.text:
We have the foundation phase and all the other
figures that show that things are moving in

1019.text:
the right direction. However, there is a need
for Government, working with teachers, parents

1026.text:
and local authorities—because Government
cannot deliver it alone—to ensure that there

1029.text:
are improvements in the future. The reality
is that we have a programme in place. Other

1035.text:
parties can say what is wrong with those programmes
or what they would do differently. The Conservatives

1038.text:
have failed signally to do that; the leader
of the opposition sits there moaning away

1043.text:
to himself, but when he is given the chance
to talk, he always runs away from it. We have

1047.text:
put in place a programme for government that
contains an education programme that will

1053.text:
move us towards improvement in 2015, and we
are confident in that. I speak as someone

1058.text:
who came from the system, whereas others in
this Chamber who complain the most did not.

1062.text:
Y Dirprwy Lywydd / The Deputy Presiding Officer:
I must say that we have a very generous procedure

1065.text:
in this Chamber for the leaders of the non-Government
parties to question, and I do not particularly

1071.text:
want to hear heckling from the leaders in
stereo while I am trying to listen to the

1076.text:
response of the First Minister.
Kirsty Williams: First Minister, you say that

1083.text:
PISA has shone a spotlight on education performance
across the world. On that international stage,

1092.text:
under the glare of that spotlight, the abject
failure of Labour's education policies have

1098.text:
been exposed for everyone to see. As a Labour
Assembly Member for 14 years, as a Cabinet

1105.text:
Member for 13 years and now as the First Minister
of our nation, are you not ashamed?

1113.text:
Carwyn Jones: No.
Kirsty Williams: Complacent, complacent, complacent.

1122.text:
You have said that it was your ambition to
be in the top 20 by 2015. We are barely scraping

1129.text:
into the top 40. Why have you consistently
promised me, this Chamber and the Welsh public

1138.text:
when questioned that we would see improvements
this year?

1142.text:
Carwyn Jones: We saw an improvement, but not
enough this year, and I have said that very

1147.text:
clearly. As the leader of the Liberal Democrats
sneered away and asked that question, I would

1151.text:
remind her of that. Let us go through it again,
because she did not listen the first time

1155.text:
round. The national literacy and numeracy
programme, the national support programme,

1160.text:
supporting professional developments, Teach
First Wales, leadership development, strengthening

1165.text:
accountability, Learning Wales, a national
model for regional working and dealing with

1169.text:
attendance and behaviour have all been put
in place since 2009. As I said, it will take

1174.text:
a little more time for these improvements
to have their full force. I say to the leader

1181.text:
of the Liberal Democrats, as I have said to
the leaders of the other parties, if you do

1184.text:
not like it, what would you change?
Kirsty Williams: First Minister, let us be

1188.text:
clear about the improvements. The reading
scores take us back to where we were in 2006.

1194.text:
Just two months ago in this Chamber, you said
to me

1199.text:
Kirsty Williams: 'I expect to see an improvement
in our PISA results in December...If you see

1204.text:
what we have done, as a Government...you will
understand why I believe that we are making

1210.text:
that improvement.'
Kirsty Williams: How can you, as the First

1213.text:
Minister, be so out of touch, ignorant and
blissfully unaware of the reality of the situation,

1219.text:
and what is going on that you could make that
statement two months ago that is so off the

1225.text:
mark?
Carwyn Jones: I have never heard a more arrogant

1227.text:
statement in this Chamber—somehow, the leader
of the Liberal Democrats is in tune with public

1233.text:
opinion and I am not. Like her, I have children
in school. I do not go on and on about it

1237.text:
like she does, but I have children in school
as well. The reality of the situation is that

1243.text:
her party is completely detached from reality
in London and has completely lost its support

1248.text:
base, and yet she talks to us about being
detached from reality. I deal with people,

1251.text:
I hold my constituency surgeries, I meet with
people on the weekend and I see what my children

1255.text:
have in school; all these things make me more
than aware of the education system. I came

1259.text:
through the state system as well. I am aware
of what the state system is able to deliver

1264.text:
and our aspirations for it in the future.
Carwyn Jones: The opposition parties have,

1271.text:
quite rightly, of course, held me to account
in terms of the PISA results, and I accept

1276.text:
that. It is my responsibility to explain to
the people of Wales what we are doing in order

1281.text:
to improve results in the future. However,
it is also the responsibility of the opposition

1287.text:
parties to outline what they would do differently.
Not once have we heard a suggestion as to

1293.text:
how things would be done differently. We accept
our responsibilities; they do not. In that

1300.text:
regard, they have signally failed.
Mohammad Asghar: 3. A wnaiff y Prif Weinidog

1307.text:
ddatganiad am lefel yr ardrethi busnes yn
ne-ddwyrain Cymru? OAQ(4)1372(FM)

1311.text:
Carwyn Jones: Yes. The level of non-domestic
rates in south-east Wales is determined on

1315.text:
the same basis as elsewhere in Wales, by multiplying
the rateable value by the national NDR multiplier.

1320.text:
Mohammad Asghar: Thank you very much for the
reply, First Minister. The proposed redevelopment

1324.text:
of Newport city centre is greatly welcomed
and will benefit businesses in the long term.

1330.text:
However, the current demolition work has caused
major disruption to pedestrian access and

1338.text:
bus stop locations, thereby reducing footfall.
Will the First Minister join me in supporting

1345.text:
Newport's chamber of trade in its efforts
to get business rates reduced for city centre

1352.text:
traders adversely affected by this redevelopment
work?

1356.text:
Carwyn Jones: These are matters for it to
discuss with the city council in Newport.

1362.text:
I am sure that the city council will consider
affordable proposals that will help to regenerate

1368.text:
the city centre.
Jocelyn Davies: First Minister, I am sure

1373.text:
that you will be aware that this weekend marks
the first Small Business Saturday in the UK.

1379.text:
I hope that you would also agree that increased
